Undergraduate Assembly President.name: Chuck Schumer
Undergraduate Assembly President.introduction: What’s up, it’s Chuck! If we haven’t met, know that I love all things Disney, Minnesota, and Capybara-related. I’ve spent the last three years on campus building community as the SAC Chair, Class Board EVP, and UA member. In this time I’ve developed a fervent love-hate relationship with Penn. The people are amazing and the resources are incredible, but the institution is flawed and well-being is undervalued. That’s why I’ll fight for “A Whole New Penn” to prioritize student needs. I would love to hear your feedback; you can always message me on Instagram @charschumer or by text at 651-900-5061!
platform points: Fixer Upper: Penn offers many great resources that are not made clear to students leading to reduced utilization (blue lights, alumni network, PennRides, etc.); we seek to increase their accessibility and awareness.
The Bare Necessities: Facilities on Penn’s campus have unclear reservation policies and costs; we seek to reduce costs and increase accessibility to spaces for student groups and events.

A Dream is a Wish: Student government often feels detached from broader student life; we seek to provide pathways for active conversation, feedback, and intentional student involvement in project work.

Shiny: Student group financial needs have not yet been fulfilled; we will implement sustainable yet accessible funding and plan collaborative funding opportunities between major student organizations.

Hakuna Matata: We will expand conceptions of student well-being beyond the pre-professional realm by improving and creating programs in mental and physical wellness, dining, sustainability, and community engagement.

Reflection: We will enable more UA representatives to attend meetings with administration directly, make advances on project work, communicate across the body to build teamwork, and increase social cohesion.

Undergraduate Assembly President.name: Xavier Shankle
Undergraduate Assembly President.introduction: Growing up in South Atlanta, I witnessed firsthand what it was like to be part of an education system that didn’t put students first. My mission as your President will be to amplify, not modify, your voices. I’m committed to building upon working relationships with administrators to create purposeful change. In my three years on UA, I have worked on initiatives to promote inclusive teaching, campus innovation, and greater social responsibility. Building a better, more equitable Penn is my top priority; you deserve a President who is relentless in advocacy, and I look forward to doing just that next session!
platform points: Penn is guilty of all the good things it chooses not to do. We will advocate for PILOTs, complete endowment divestment, and transparency regarding Penn’s role in gentrification developments in Philadelphia.

Popping the Penn Bubble by fostering inclusive spaces for meaningful community engagement, streamlining ways for Philadelphia students to have direct access to Penn, and leveraging institutional resources for good.

Advocating for academic policies and practices that ensure classes facilitate meaningful engagement. We will implement academic wellness initiatives, improve professor accountability and promote inclusive teaching practices.

Facilitating purposeful partnerships between historically marginalized students, organizations, and Penn administrators to ensure students are seen, actively listened to, and supported to fulfill pertinent needs.

Prioritizing mental health and wellness for Penn students by advocating for high-quality and accessible resources, facilitating destigmatizing conversations, and supporting community-driven initiatives to improve overall well-being on campus.

Undergraduate Assembly VP.name: Maya El-Sharif
Undergraduate Assembly VP.introduction: Hiya I’m Maya and I am running to be your UA VP. While I usually hate running, running for student government has been a central part of my Penn experience. While many find love for finance, the closest I have gotten is my newfound ick for funding on Penn’s campus. In my positions, I have worked on making funding more accessible and will continue to do if elected. My love for Penn is best seen in my extracurriculars, so improving the lives of student groups and students to create a Whole New Penn is my largest priority.
platform points: Fixer Upper: Penn offers many great resources that are not made clear to students leading to reduced utilization (blue lights, alumni network, PennRides, etc.); we seek to increase their accessibility and awareness.
The Bare Necessities: Facilities on Penn’s campus have unclear reservation policies and costs; we seek to reduce costs and increase accessibility to spaces for student groups and events.

A Dream is a Wish: Student government often feels detached from broader student life; we seek to provide pathways for active conversation, feedback, and intentional student involvement in project work.

Shiny: Student group financial needs have not yet been fulfilled; we will implement sustainable yet accessible funding and plan collaborative funding opportunities between major student organizations.

Hakuna Matata: We will expand conceptions of student well-being beyond the pre-professional realm by improving and creating programs in mental and physical wellness, dining, sustainability, and community engagement.

Reflection: We will enable more UA representatives to attend meetings with administration directly, make advances on project work, communicate across the body to build teamwork, and increase social cohesion.

Undergraduate Assembly VP.name: Hannah Liu
Undergraduate Assembly VP.introduction: Hello everyone! My name is Hannah Liu, and I’m running for UA Vice President. This past year, I served as the UA Secretary and was the youngest member on the UA Executive Board. Two main initiatives that I have established include an excused absence policy for student athletes and an expansion of the Airport Shuttle program to make it more accessible throughout the year. As UA VP, I want to continue supporting the variety of groups on campus while also bringing awareness to issues that have yet to be brought up. Vote for Hannah Liu, the best candidate for you!
platform points: Transportation Accessibility: Continue to expand the Airport Shuttle program by extending its dates to potentially include Winter Break and Fall Break and work on securing return trips from the airport

Diversity and Advocacy: Uplift the voices of advocacy groups by frequently meeting with groups, creating connections between the groups and administrators, and providing them with the resources to succeed

Raising Awareness: Bring up issues that have little to no current awareness surrounding it, such as pain points experienced by international students, student athletes, performing arts groups, and transfer students
Accountability: Ensure that administrators are aware of the student advocacy movements on campus as well as the most pressing issues for students while also urging them to help take action

Tackling student problems: Address a variety of student needs, such as addressing the lack of lower-cost housing options, encouraging subsidization student travel expenses, and bringing awareness to mental health resources
Sustainability: Implement and encourage sustainable initiatives in different areas of Penn, such as in the College Houses and dining halls

Undergraduate Assembly VP.name: Ranim Albarkawi
Undergraduate Assembly VP.introduction: Hi! My name is Ranim and I am a junior from Philadelphia. Throughout my time at Penn, my goal has always been to empower community  members in any way possible. I am driven to action by the prospect of creating positive change for all around me. This passion led me to be a part of the UA for the past two years, where I have had the opportunity to work with students and administrators to improve campus life and address student issues. As Vice President, I will remain dedicated to advocating for our voices to be heard, and I look forward to continuing to make a difference both on and off campus.
platform points: Popping the Penn Bubble by fostering inclusive spaces for meaningful community engagement, streamlining ways for Philadelphia students to have direct access to Penn, and leveraging institutional resources for good.

Penn is guilty of all the good things it chooses not to do. We will advocate for PILOTs, complete endowment divestment, and transparency regarding Penn’s role in gentrification developments in Philadelphia.

Advocating for academic policies and practices that ensure classes facilitate meaningful engagement. We will implement academic wellness initiatives, improve professor accountability and promote inclusive teaching practices.

Facilitating purposeful partnerships between historically marginalized students, organizations, and Penn administrators to ensure students are seen, actively listened to, and worked with to fulfill pertinent needs.

Prioritizing mental health and wellness for Penn students by advocating for accessible resources, destigmatizing conversations, and supporting community-driven initiatives to improve overall well-being on campus.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Jaideep Grewal
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hello! My name is Jaideep Grewal and I am running to be an Undergraduate Assembly representative. I believe I have the perfect mix of experience, diligence, enthusiasm, optimism, and drive to lead our class this year and represent YOUR needs. I strive to make the next school year as fun and successful as possible.
platform points: FUN: Classes, clubs, and school in general are stressful. I commit to establishing as many fun social events as possible (with free food, of course).
PRINTERS: Especially for those in the quad and in CAS, we have to take a long trek to find a printer. I commit to making printers more accessible everywhere.
FACILITIES: I commit to establishing more routine cleanings of bathrooms and all public areas. Temperature fluctuations will also be taken care of.
MENTAL HEALTH: Many general resources are listed on campus pages, but are they really accessible? I commit to making mental health resources easily accessible through virtual consults.
FOOD/DRINKS: I commit to having vending machines in every house, and easy pick-up points for food deliveries at the entrances of every house.
CLUBS/CLASSES: I commit to concentrating all club apps into one common application and making Path@Penn easier to use.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Ria Ellendula
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: ​​Hi! My name is Ria Ellendula, and I’m running to be re-elected as a UA College Representative and Class Board Vice President. This year, I served as the UA Equity and Inclusion Director. I have worked to establish the pilot program for free menstrual products in Hill and advocate for free menstrual products on campus. Through the Class Board, I have been able to facilitate events, such as Holi, Econ Scream, etc. I want to improve the student experience and would appreciate your vote for re-election! Please reach out to me at @riaell@sas.upenn.edu for any more questions!
platform points: Advocating for free menstrual products throughout campus and residential buildings.
Supporting the vision and the values of various identity-based campus organizations.
Opening up channels of communication between students and student government representatives
Facilitating class-wide spirit events that are both inclusive and exciting!

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Yash Mahajan
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hi! I'm Yash Mahajan, and I'm running for re-election for the Undergraduate Assembly and to become the Class of 2025's VP External! I have really enjoyed my time at Penn and on the UA, and would love the opportunity to continue giving back to the Penn community by working on DEI, sustainability, and school spirit. As an international student, I have recognised the need to feel 'integrated' into the Penn community, and I want to ensure every student feels not only integrated, but seen, heard and accommodated for. To see my UA projects (sustainability/DEI), visit pennua.org/annual-reports
platform points: Academic Wellness: • Ensure all courses release at least one grade prior to drop and P/F deadlines • Ensure all courses provide late days • Increase mid-semester feedback surveys

Penn Dining: • Create reimbursement schemes for Dining Plans in face of health violations/closures • Survey students to modify dining hours • Create price-matching frameworks to make on-campus food more accessible

DEI (Course Registration): • Create an opt-out lottery system to replace add-drop process—ensuring equal opportunity to enroll regardless of wifi, location or work schedule • Check UA annual report for full project proposal

Accommodations: • Provide stipends for summer courses, textbooks etc through SRFS • Allow petitions for early move-in decisions • Modify dormitory air-conditioning policies • Increase RA and event funding
Building Community: • Organise year-wide and major-wide study breaks with food and faculty • Support student groups by showcasing different organisations on weekly College Green exhibitions

Sustainability: • Provide reusable cups for dining halls and discounts in on-campus cafes • Increase availability of compost bins and education • Increase accessibility to maps of on-campus water refill stations

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Maya El-Sharif
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hiya I’m Maya and I am running to be your UA Representative. While I usually hate running, running for student government has been a central part of my Penn experience. While many find love for finance, the closest I have gotten is my newfound ick for funding on Penn’s campus. In my positions, I have worked on making funding more accessible and will continue to do if elected. My love for Penn is best seen in my extracurriculars, so improving the lives of student groups and students to create a Whole New Penn is my largest priority.
platform points: Fixer Upper: Penn offers many great resources that are not made clear to students leading to reduced utilization (blue lights, alumni network, PennRides, etc.); we seek to increase their accessibility and awareness.
The Bare Necessities: Facilities on Penn’s campus have unclear reservation policies and costs; we seek to reduce costs and increase accessibility to spaces for student groups and events.

A Dream is a Wish: Student government often feels detached from broader student life; we seek to provide pathways for active conversation, feedback, and intentional student involvement in project work.

Shiny: Student group financial needs have not yet been fulfilled; we will implement sustainable yet accessible funding and plan collaborative funding opportunities between major student organizations.

Hakuna Matata: We will expand conceptions of student well-being beyond the pre-professional realm by improving and creating programs in mental and physical wellness, dining, sustainability, and community engagement.

Reflection: We will enable more UA representatives to attend meetings with administration directly, make advances on project work, communicate across the body to build teamwork, and increase social cohesion.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Eric Lee
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Eric is a freshman in the College studying biochemistry and biophysics. This past academic year, he enjoyed serving on both the Class Board and Undergraduate Assembly, where he helped to plan social programming for the Class of 2026 (he's grateful for "Skate Night" being a hit!) and worked with administrators such as the Netter Center coordinators to improve student life at Penn. He would love to continue his work and interact with classmates through Penn's student government. Outside of class and Penn Student Government, Eric enjoys running, playing the violin, and going to Chinatown for plump baozi buns.
platform points: Hosting class-wide "office hours" to hear the concerns and desires of the Class of 2026—we want to hear what you want to happen.
Working with the Dining Advisory Board to create a more established dumpling bar at dining halls or partnering with a new dumpling vendor in dining cafes, as dumplings appear to be in high demand.
Opening a more permanent merch store that sells apparel exclusive to the Class of 2026.

Creating an external seat to the Netter Center to promote civic engagement and Community Service. The external seat holder will work on administrative tasks to support volunteering groups, such as providing SEPTA cards for transportation.
Making Houston Hall the center of student socialization, especially for underclassmen, through a Houston Hall email list and new events like weekly cuisine sampling.
Working with Penn Transit to include stops further off campus to promote exploration in Philadelphia and service to the community outside Penn's campus.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Chuck Schumer
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: What’s up, it’s Chuck! If we haven’t met, know that I love all things Disney, Minnesota, and Capybara-related. I’ve spent the last three years on campus building community as the SAC Chair, Class Board EVP, and UA member. In this time I’ve developed a fervent love-hate relationship with Penn. The people are amazing and the resources are incredible, but the institution is flawed and well-being is undervalued. That’s why I’ll fight for “A Whole New Penn” to prioritize student needs. I would love to hear your feedback; you can always message me on Instagram @charschumer or by text at 651-900-5061!
platform points: Fixer Upper: Penn offers many great resources that are not made clear to students leading to reduced utilization (blue lights, alumni network, PennRides, etc.); we seek to increase their accessibility and awareness.
The Bare Necessities: Facilities on Penn’s campus have unclear reservation policies and costs; we seek to reduce costs and increase accessibility to spaces for student groups and events.

A Dream is a Wish: Student government often feels detached from broader student life; we seek to provide pathways for active conversation, feedback, and intentional student involvement in project work.

Shiny: Student group financial needs have not yet been fulfilled; we will implement sustainable yet accessible funding and plan collaborative funding opportunities between major student organizations.

Hakuna Matata: We will expand conceptions of student well-being beyond the pre-professional realm by improving and creating programs in mental and physical wellness, dining, sustainability, and community engagement.

Reflection: We will enable more UA representatives to attend meetings with administration directly, make advances on project work, communicate across the body to build teamwork, and increase social cohesion.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Mackenzie "Mack" Sleeman
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hey everyone! My name is Mackenzie Sleeman, I am a New Yorker, and a sophomore transfer student from Villanova University studying PPE. I am rerunning for the Undergraduate Assembly because my tangible efforts as New Transfer Representative have enabled me to experience the passion that emerges while serving an underrepresented community. As a College Representative, I hope to continue to employ my fresh, unique perspective to challenge the traditional Penn academic environment. In my free time, I love to go on walks with my little sister, watch Formula One, and play tennis with friends.
platform points: Popping the Penn Bubble: Sponsor community and wellness events between Penn and neighboring institutions (Villanova/Temple) to raise awareness of Penn Face and stressors rooted in Penn’s pre-professional environment.
XCAT Advisory Board: A group of students to oversee the XCAT process to identify problems that continue to persist after the launch of the XCAT system last year.

Transfer Advising: Continue work with administration to create a transfer advisor, that is retained yearly, who will build the knowledge required to fully assist transfers in their acclimation to Penn.
Transfer Hub: To find a space on campus to promote transfer community, or to access funding to modernize and better furnish the common room within the Transfer Living Community.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Juan Lopez
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hello Penn, My name is Juan Lopez and I am excited to run for UA CAS Representative. I am majoring in Political Science and I’m from the Bay Area. I was a New Student Rep for the UA and am working closely with the Equity and Inclusion committee. While being in UA, I worked closely with the FGLI community and helped there be more resources to help incoming FGLI students adjust to Penn better. I want to work more with Penn’s Math curriculum and hopefully I can continue that work.
platform points: I’ll make sure to advocate for the needs of every student at Penn! You’ll all have my socials or email and can let me know of any questions or concerns.
As I’ll be in the loop on most things, I will make sure to let everyone know of anything that might not be beneficial to the student body.
Making Penn a more collaborative community rather than a competitive one!
Work with Financial aid to have more free events on campus or have many things be more accessible to everyone.
Support the FGLI community with more resources to succeed at Penn and create a  strong community within one another!
I will make sure everyone has fun through it all. I believe not everything needs to be serious and more interactions with the student body is necessary!

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Leo Solga
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Salutations, my name is Leo Solga! I am running for reelection to the Undergraduate Assembly as a representative from the College. Over the last year, I’ve worked tirelessly to improve the student experience. If re-elected, I intend to continue working towards universal free printing, expanding the airport shuttle service, and fighting the uphill battle to improve Penn Dining. Please let me know if you have any questions, concerns, or compliments! I will be campaigning with a notebook to write down your ideas. Vote for Leo Solga - Bowtie Rep! Godspeed.
platform points: Experience - Over the last year my main extracurricular commitment has been to serve on the Undergraduate Assembly. My focus has been working to improve dining, housing, and transportation.
Focus - If elected, serving on the Undergraduate Assembly will remain my primary extracurricular commitment.
Transparency - I will continue to be transparent with inquiring members of the student body regarding my activities on the UA as well as the actions of the assembly.
Policy - I have specific, actionable plans to move ahead with the changes I hope to make.
Connections - Having met Penn admin and their subcontractors who work in various areas of university life, I have some of the needed connections to get things done.
Style - If elected, you can bet I will continue my tradition of showing up to every UA meeting in a dapper bowtie.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Hannah Liu
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hello everyone! My name is Hannah Liu, and I’m running for UA Vice President. This past year, I served as the UA Secretary and was the youngest member on the UA Executive Board. Two main initiatives that I have established include an excused absence policy for student athletes and an expansion of the Airport Shuttle program to make it more accessible throughout the year. As College Rep, I want to continue supporting the variety of groups on campus while also bringing awareness to issues that have yet to be brought up. Vote for Hannah Liu, the best candidate for you!
platform points: Transportation Accessibility: Continue to expand the Airport Shuttle program by extending its dates to potentially include Winter Break and Fall Break and work on securing return trips from the airport

Diversity and Advocacy: Uplift the voices of advocacy groups by frequently meeting with groups, creating connections between the groups and administrators, and providing them with the resources to succeed
Accountability: Ensure that administrators are aware of the student advocacy movements on campus as well as the most pressing issues for students while also urging them to help take action

Awareness: Bring up issues that have little to no current awareness surrounding it, such as pain points experienced by international students, student athletes, performing arts groups, and transfer students

Tackling student problems: Address a variety of student needs, such as addressing the lack of lower-cost housing options, encouraging subsidization student travel expenses, and bringing awareness to mental health resources
Sustainability: Implement and encourage sustainable initiatives in different areas of Penn, such as in the College Houses and dining halls

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Cody Eskandarian
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hey! My name is Cody Eskandarian and I’m a junior studying chemistry and physics from New York. I’m running for re-election for Class Board and UA because I’ve got innovative ideas that I’m excited to bring to Penn that you can read about below! Outside of my initiatives, I bring a lot to the table; tenacity, creativity, enthusiasm, and most importantly, I make sure that the people around me have fun as we work together as a team. I’m here to make quality of life improvements through the UA, and cultivate an unforgettable senior year for the class of ‘24.
platform points: Introduce shuttles that take students to home goods stores (Walmart/Target) during NSO (already in progress with Penn administration!!)
Sports tournaments! If you enjoyed our dodgeball and basketball tournaments, I want to organize even more like volleyball, soccer, spikeball, etc.
Bolster student voices on dining hall sanitation issues
Develop more local service opportunities in West Philadelphia, such as beautifying schools and providing food for those in need
Make Feb Club for the class of ‘24 an absolute movie

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Koustav Datta
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hey everyone! My name is Koustav Datta and I hope to serve as a CAS Representative for the UA and as a College Chair for the Class of 2026. I have always loved Student Government, so I would thoroughly appreciate it if I would be able to continue doing what I love. If elected, I promise to create a tighter-knit community within the Class of 2026 through planned social events, and introduce policy to ensure all students have equitable access to materials. I love meeting new people while playing soccer, the piano, and chess, so please introduce yourself if you see me around campus :).
platform points: Mental Health - More people need to be informed about mental health counseling opportunities present around Penn's Campus in order to reduce the presence of "PennFace", as this is closely intertwined with mental health.
Math and Science Workshops - Additional workshops will be presented before every Friday quiz for math classes and before science-related midterms/finals to bolster preparation for exams.
Penn Merch - If possible, more free Penn Class of 2026 merchandise should be available to students so that students can show off their school pride. Go Quakers!
Diversity Days - Roughly once a month, students from different backgrounds would be asked create and showcase their culinary skills by having a potluck with food originating around the world.

Communication - Currently, there is a limited number of avenues for communication between students and administration regarding pressing issues. Improving and increasing the number of such avenues should be a priority for both groups of people.

Volunteering Opportunities - More volunteering opportunities should be presented to Penn students around Penn's campus and in West Philadelphia, specifically in the form of academic opportunities or sustainability initiatives.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Shikhar Gupta
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: What’s up! My name is Shikhar Gupta and I am a freshman studying biochemistry in the College. To me, the absolute BEST part of the College is the diversity within it, however, I still feel so disconnected from other majors. I want to begin strengthening relationships between College students through coordinated course advising sessions and programs similar to Wharton Cohorts. Additionally, I want to continue my projects from the past year, which you can read about below! Let’s work together to make it a priority to learn from one another and build a stronger sense of community among College students.
platform points: Developing a program amongst college students that encourages connections between classes and majors, similar to Wharton Cohorts.
Airport Shuttles! I want to expand it to Winter and Spring breaks and to both departures and arrivals, possibly collaborating with services like Uber and Lyft (already in the works!)
Introduce the confusing world of Penn Transit to students through accessible platforms like a TAP module, preceptorial, RA programming, and field trips (already in the works!)
Host coordinated course advising sessions where students can speak with upperclassmen, advisors, and each other about courses and advanced registration.
BREAD! Did you know that the bread thrown at football games is fresh? What a waste! I want to collaborate with local businesses to sustainably reuse freshly expired bread for throwing.
LISTEN to your ideas regarding anything Penn!

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Xandro Xu
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: My name is Xandro Xu and I am seeking your vote for re-election as a UA College Representative and Class of 2025 College Chair! As a queer person of color, I am passionate about building community and leading efforts in diversity, equity, and inclusion. This past year on the UA, I spearheaded an initiative with SHAC Counseling to better understand students' experiences with counseling and how well they feel their identities represented. I hope to continue to make positive impact through organizing events and offering students a safe space to address their concerns. Remember, Xu is the one for you!
platform points: Community - Organizing of events that are centered around building genuine connections with other students.
Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion - Spearheading initiatives to increase student inclusion in various spaces on campus (i.e. clubs, research labs)
Accessibility - Working to increase equitable and widespread access to opportunities across the student body, in particular FGLI and disabled populations.
Accountability and Transparency - Improved transparency between Penn administration and the study body to establish a renewed compact of trust and legitimacy.
Advocacy - Advocating for FGLI, URM, Disabled, and LGBTQIA+ members of the Penn community.

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Isaac Tang
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hello! I’m Isaac Tang and I’m from Miami. I’m currently studying Math (that is the most boring fact about me, I promise). Outside of the classroom, I’m in Counterparts, one of Penn’s acapella groups, and my dream is to become a professor. I'm running to represent you because I’d love to get to know each of you good looking people, and bring our class and community together through fun, educational events because, as Mr. Worldwide once sang, “One’s company, two’s a crowd and three’s a party.” We have a little more than three students, but we’ll make it work.
platform points: Create opportunities for students to get involved in local Philadelphia community by partnering with the Netter Center and diversifying ABCS (Academically Based Community Service Courses) to fulfill course requirements
Host more classwide events to display Penn’s performing and visual arts, allowing groups to gain more publicity and opportunities to showcase their hard work
Publicize and increase the capacity of Weingarten tutoring programs so more students can learn in smaller groups
Expand our student body’s cultural knowledge through free food and culinary events
Encourage our class to explore the greater Philadelphia community (and beyond Pennsylvania) through social events and parties downtown
Promote class spirit through more free Penn merchandise

College of Arts and Sciences Representat.name: Michel Collet
College of Arts and Sciences Representat.introduction: Hi, my name is Michel. I am a Neuroscience major in the College of Arts and Sciences and I am running for UA representative. My past experiences in leadership include being the Co-president of Penn Special Olympics, serving on my high school student government, and directing several Model United Nations conferences. I'm running for UA because I believe that I can do a great job in relaying and amplifying student opinions. Furthemore, I am committed to maximizing the undergraduate experience of Penn students’ by proposing modifications to UA’s budget expenditures and creating new programs that aid students.
platform points: Allow students to control more of UA budget
Improve communication between UA and the general student body
Create a much better penn upperclassmen to lower classmen mentor system to those who are interested in it.
Make adjustments to inefficiencies on Penn scheduling apps.
Improve the level of communication that course planning counsellors have with all students.
Increase school-planned events for freshman during NSO to improve transition.

Wharton Representative.name: Michelle Chen
Wharton Representative.introduction: Hi! I’m running to be re-elected on Class Board and UA as the VP of External and a Wharton Rep. This past year, I’ve had the opportunity to work on many projects in both branches, ranging from Late Night Skate night to improving accessibility of resources for students. I hope to continue these initiatives in the following year, and maintain transparency, communication, and advocacy on behalf and for my class!
platform points: Transparency- value class input through feedback via Social Media platforms
Communication- update student body regularly regarding upcoming events
Advocacy- represent the student body by tackling issues that are important to maintaining equity within the body

Wharton Representative.name: Shan Shan Liang
Wharton Representative.introduction: Hi everyone, my name is Shan Shan Liang, and I am a junior in Wharton studying Finance and Business Analytics. I'm from Johnson City, Tennessee, and I have served on both Class Board and Undergraduate Assembly for 3 years. I love the people I have met and the work we have done! I hope to keep making an impact through student government in my senior at Penn. Please email me (shan9318@wharton.upenn.edu) if you have any thoughts for what you want to see in our last year.
platform points: Feb Club - the best Feb Club this school has seen in 4 years!
DEI - focus on diversity and inclusion events, along with more partnerships with cultural groups on campus
Free events - free food, free merch, anything to make senior year the best!

Wharton Representative.name: Keshav Ramesh
Wharton Representative.introduction: Hey there! I’m Keshav Ramesh, and I’m running for reelection to the UA after serving as your Wharton Representative during the past year. I’m very passionate about academic initiatives that benefit the student population, increasing diversity and representation in spaces across campus, and fostering connections between students and administration. I’ve worked on projects from student trustee representation to increasing the transparency of study abroad programs to organizing airport shuttles for students. If you have any questions feel free to reach out at keshmesh@wharton.upenn.edu!
platform points: Working with other UA representatives to organize more community-building events and volunteer opportunities in both Penn and the wider West Philadelphia region.
Pursuing the goal of undergraduate and graduate student representation on the Penn Board of Trustees (with voting rights) and all trustee committees on which students can serve.
Establishing essay and interview workshops for club applications at the start of each semester, in which underclassmen can pair up with upperclassmen to navigate extracurriculars at Penn.

Partnering with cultural and ethnic student organizations on campus to create and implement legislation that directly improves diversity, equity, and inclusion in professionally-aligned spaces at Penn.
Expanding the current Airport Shuttles program from Thanksgiving and Spring Break to include the weeks of Fall Break and the return to campus period post-Winter Break.

Connecting undergraduates with alumni of Penn Student Government and the University of Pennsylvania who have embarked on careers in government, politics, law, and public policy through student-led career development programs.

Wharton Representative.name: Sarah Ali
Wharton Representative.introduction: Hi everyone, I'm Sarah, a freshman from Abu Dhabi, UAE. I'm planning on majoring in Finance and Statistics at Wharton, and I'm running for Wharton Representative in the Undergraduate Assembly. I've decided to run for this position to make a meaningful contribution to the student body and advocate for causes and initiatives I'm passionate about, and represent the needs and interests of my peers. If elected, I will work tirelessly to ensure that Wharton students have a voice in campus decision-making processes and that our concerns are heard and addressed. Together, we can create a better and more inclusive campus community. Thank you for your support!
platform points: Being in the undergraduate assembly, I am an advocate for minority groups, such as international and ethnic populations like myself. I aim to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion on campus.

As a vegetarian, I feel as though Penn doesn’t cater to different dietary restrictions. Therefore, I would like to bring more food options for those that are vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free to ensure students do not have to look elsewhere for food.

Getting into Wharton clubs can be tough! But it should not be. Everyone at Wharton is equally deserving and club recruiting can really put one’s self-esteem down. Using my platform I would make sure clubs are being inclusive and thoughtful of their recruiting process.

College can be difficult, but reaching out for help can be even harder. I would like to make mental health resources readily available so asking for help is effortless. This way students are more comfortable with taking the next step to improving their state of mind and consequently their academics!

I would work to promote financial literacy and wellness among undergraduate students and advocate for policies and initiatives that support affordable education, student loan forgiveness, and financial aid.

I would like to focus on promoting leadership development opportunities for undergraduate students, such as organizing workshops, mentorship programs, or networking events. I also want to advocate for policies that support student leadership and development.

SEAS Representative.name: Faraz Rahman
SEAS Representative.introduction:
Hi my name is Faraz and I am the incumbent candidate for the Class Board engineering chair. During Class Board, I have been responsible for a number of events including Econ Scream and Skate Nights.

This year, I will also be running for Undergraduate Assembly. I have experience with UA adjacent committees including Dining Advisory Board and Residential Services Advisory Board. Some of my accomplishments on these boards include


- producing videos for accepted seniors to learn about housing on campus.
- expanding KCECHs/Mclelands dining hours
- increasing to Halal/Kosher availability at places such as Gourmet Grocer and Accenture Cafe
platform points: Increasing Equity of Food Plans for those with food restrictions (ie Vegan/Halal/Kosher/etc.)
Providing Engineering clubs better access to social funds so students can pay less out of pocket.

SEAS Representative.name: Iniyaal Raguraj
SEAS Representative.introduction: From doing Bhangra until 4 AM to writing sketch comedy until I sleep, a lot of people tell me I'm an engineering student by name only. I'm wrapping up my freshman year as a CIS major, and it's been tough balancing my extracurricular interests with my (unfortunate) affinity toward engineering. I also really struggle with anxiety, and I've experienced first-hand how overwhelming things can get here in the eQuad when you also want to engage with all the things that bring you joy. But–I don't think all hope is lost. Let's break the stereotype and find some balance together.
platform points: Workload: I want to build in 2 resources: course contacts & stress guides. We need tools that can show us how to ask for help and deal with falling behind.
Campus-wide printing access: we're not always in Towne–SEAS printing dollars & services should work across campus regardless of a building's school affiliation.

Interdisciplinary coursework & opportunities: I want to encourage the development of mini-courses or concentrations in majors that allow us to engage more easily with interests that complement our majors.
Priority GSR booking access: we don't have enough study spaces, let alone for Engineering students on campus. We need increased and 24-hour access to safe, comfortable study spaces.

SEAS Representative.name: Chandler Cheung
SEAS Representative.introduction: Hi! I am a sophomore in SEAS studying computer science. This past year on the UA, I have worked on various projects ranging from creating a permanent vigil space on campus to updating the list of current courses on the CIS department website to adding more options for CIS concentrations. Next session, I will continue to advocate for student voices to be heard to admin and drive change to improve student life on campus. Please let me know if you have any questions or want to talk!

SEAS Representative.name: Phillip Gao
SEAS Representative.introduction: Hi everyone! My name is Phillip Gao, and I am excited to announce my candidacy for the Engineering Representative position on the Undergraduate Assembly. If elected, I plan to bridge the gap between the administration and the student body, bringing forth issues that affect Penn students on a day-to-day basis. As the Vice President of the Engineering Student Activities Council, I’ve worked to eliminate the financial barriers to joining clubs and to organize engaging school-wide activities that benefit the undergraduate population. I’d really appreciate your support in my campaign. So act now, vote for Gao!
platform points: Advocate for group study rooms in the new engineering buildings (Amy Gutmann Hall & Vagelos Laboratory for Energy Science and Technology)
Increase funding for engineering clubs and organizations
Emphasize mental health resources for the student body
Centralize the club recruiting process to reduce student stress
Promote student volunteering opportunities with the Netter Center/PESTLE
Establish alumni-student connections and mentorships
